content.webTitle: FA to speed up disciplinary process

fields.headline: FA to speed up disciplinary process
fields.bodyText: The Football Association has unveiled a new code designed to speed up the disciplinary process. The new code will be implemented as a pilot scheme next season in the Premier League, Football League and Conference. The FA called on former player Brendon Batson to manage the project which is the result of lengthy consultations with players, managers and referees. The procedures, which meet Fifa requirements, fall into three main categories: automatic suspensions for incidents seen and dealt with by the referee; incidents not seen by the referee; and incidents seen by the referee but out of his jurisdiction. Under the new code, suspensions will come into effect immediately, unless a claim for wrongful dismissal is lodged by 12pm the next working day. Under current regulations suspensions come into effect 14 days after a game. Appeals will only be permitted if the ban exceeds three matches. For more complex cases - such as doping, child protection and financial matters - the disciplinary commissions will control the speed of the process but these will still be dealt with within 28 days. Bans following an accumulation of yellow cards - five, 10, 15 - will come into effect seven days after the last card rather than the current 14. A new and separate code of conduct regarding doping matters is set to be unveiled at the end of this month. FA chief executive Mark Palios said: "When I travelled around the grounds the one call I got more than any other from everyone within the game was the need to address the speed with which we deal with disciplinary cases and we believe we have now done that. "This is the most far-reaching review of the disciplinary process in the game since the mid 1990s and we need the clubs and the players to play their part." Players who attempt to manipulate the system by lodging weak appeals run the risk of being hit with harder penalties. "This is what football wanted and what football needs," added Palios.
